title: (x) Modern, square font used in movie prop - Serpentine {Kevin Bulmer (self)}
content:
Hi Everyone. I hope you can help me with this.

The font I am trying to ID is a relatively contemporary, square faced sans-serif.  
I am not sure that the “A” in this sample is accurate to the font; because of the way this has been used on a movie prop it is possible they “tweaked” the A to better match the source image.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080203103019im_/http:/typophile.com/files/USPS_4881.gif)

This is a blown up sample of the original. The rounding on the corners might be a result of my blowing the fuzzy image up and sharpening it.

This is driving me nuts. I am sure I have seen this font before. I’m pretty sure I used it as a dry transfer lettering in the 1980’s. It is also making me think of Star Trek.

Can anybody help?

 [‹ (x) Typophile logo & background of homepage - H&FJ Gotham, Featured Face {Jan E}](http://web.archive.org/web/20080203103019/http:/typophile.com/node/41606 "Go to previous forum topic") [Gaby Imports logo decorative serif face w/ swashes & curls ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080203103019/http:/typophile.com/node/41602 "Go to next forum topic")
author: KevinB

comments.content:
Found it!  
It’s a modified version of Serpentine Medium Oblique.  
Looking at the original, tiny, fuzzy image I am sure that is the original font. The “A” must have been tweaked to match the distinctive United States Postal Service logo.
